data.title: GG23 OSS - Developer Tooling and Libraries

questions.query: Telegram Handle We Can Use To Contact You
Link to your Public Group Chat
Have you participated in a previous Gitcoin Grants Round? If so, please name the rounds or link the builder profile associated with previous rounds
Provide a brief overview of your tool, library, or framework. What specific problem or inefficiency in the development process does it address?
questions.explanation:
**Lexon enables smart contracts that read like plain English.**  


---


Lexon texts are plain English program code, making smart contracts readable for all, by deterministically compiling English to Solidity.    

Lexon is a plain-text programming language for law and smart contracts. It is the first of a new generation of languages. Its grammar describes the intersection of natural human language and higher order logic.

This addresses the problem that non-programmers—businesspeople, legal professionals, or private citizens—know better what they want to express than the programmers they have to work with but today cannot write nor verify smart contracts themselves. Lexon makes everything plain English.

questions.query: How does your project reduce development barriers, improve efficiency, or enhance the security of Web3 projects? Please provide specific examples or metrics if available.
questions.explanation:
Lexon helps overcoming the hurdles to mainstreaming crypto, because it reduces the opaqueness of smart contract technology, making it more transparent and acceptable.



This can solve the question, whether smart contracts are real contracts. With Lexon, an English-language legal agreement and the smart contract become the same.



This also addresses the problem of the exclusion of weaker and poorer demographics from digital commerce: Lexon can enable a very long tail of markets that cannot exist at this point, because the cost of policing them would be higher than their margins. Crypto should in theory be able to do that on its own. But Lexon might provide the necessary accessibility and free compatibility with the existing legal system.



And Lexon addresses the dilemma that a fork-lift replacement of many existing processes by crypto is unrealistic. Instead, Lexon makes crypto “backwards compatible” —simply: readable— which allows for a smooth step-by-step transition. Because language is the medium of commerce and law. Lexon makes crypto compatible with the legacy protocol. This is no aphorism. It is very concrete and powerful.

For an example how operating agreements of companies might look in the future, written in Lexon, see the [Oversimplicated DAO](https://www.lexon.org/oversimplicated.html).

questions.query: Describe the current usage and support for your tool within the developer community. This could include GitHub stars, downloads, or testimonials from developers.
questions.explanation:
Lexon is still in early stage 0.3 but has garnered a community of high-powered individuals and academic recognition in the fields of law and computational law.

These include, Brian Fox, creator of bash, Thomas Hardjono, director at MIT Medialabs, asst. prof. Carla Reyes, director of the U.S. trade law reform commission, Constance Choi, founder of COALA, founding GC at Kraken, Rob Stupay of Remix, T. J. Saw, co-founder of Parity, David Bovil, Chris Wray formerly of Mattereum, Dani Nemet of NYM, who invented the term "liquid democracy", Marina Markezic co-founder European Crypto Initiative, Dominic Williams, founder of Dfinity, Stan Stalnaker, founder of Hub Culture, Ed Hesse co-founder Grid Singularity, Rick Dudley, founder of Vulcanize and many more.

Papers are linked here: https://www.lexon.org/papers.html

Books about Lexon here: https://www.lexon.org/books.html for example, https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0D8Y6F8DW

questions.query: Outline your project's roadmap and how the grant funds will be used to achieve your development goals.
questions.explanation:
The current development goal is Lexon 0.4, which will augment the expressiveness of the language to write DAOs in it. (See [Oversimplicated](https://www.lexon.org/oversimplicated.html)).

There are concretely the following keywords and grammar structures to be added:



•	appoint ... as new [assignment operator]
•	based on ... [function parameter marker]
•	certify ... as ... [assignment operator]
•	create  [object creation operator]
•	defined: if ... then ... else [conditional definition flow operator]
•	divided by ... [math operator]
•	for all ... [object-iterating loop construct]
•	given [transparent wrapper]
•	half of [math operator]
•	in any other case [flow structure]
•	In either case [flow operator]
•	in every case [flow structure]
•	increase ... by ... [math operator]
•	increased by ... [math operator]
•	is ... already [transparent wrapper]
•	it is not the case that [Boolean negation operator]
•	itself [grammatical wrapper]
•	means [alternate definition operator]
•	Monday to Sunday [dynamic time constants]
•	number of [transparent type wrapper]
•	On [dynamic and fix time operator]
•	on record [transparent wrapper]
•	one [number constant]
•	operating agreement [source start keyword]
•	otherwise [conditional flow branch]
•	provided ... : [conditional construct keyword]
•	provided that [conditional construct keyword]
•	recorded number of [transparent wrapper]
•	reduce [math operator]
•	submit [object creation operator]
•	there is [Boolean operator]
•	there is no ... [assignment operator]
•	times [multiplication operator]
•	with that [flow structure]
•	zero [number constant]

This list describes what is needed over the current Lexon 0.3 version to compile the example DAO overzero.lex. It approximates the minimal set of words needed to create DAOs. 

The keywords are fundamental operators, similar to in other programming languages if, for, or * /. There are further keywords and grammar constructs identified that will be added once the implementation of this set is stable.

questions.query: For any project deploying smart contracts on blockchain networks, please list all your deployer addresses and their corresponding blockchain networks. Use this format for each entry: [deployer_address], [chain_id]—for example, 0x123abc..., 42161 (This represents a deployer address on the Arbitrum network). Please include a separate line for each unique deployer address and blockchain combination.
